body: Earlier in the presentation Mr. Brown makes reference to the fact that at its root, design is a"human-scented process", by which he means that it doesn't stand as its own autonomous field. Rather, it starts with the subject (who is being designed for?) and works backwards from there. Thus, to be an effective designer one must be familiar with the demographic of those they are designing for. When it comes to our course projects, it may be important to consider a larger narrative and how the project fits into it. In particular, to achieve this will mean becoming familiar with our classmates and the course as a whole.

I always thought good design was 50/50. For instance, 50% time and effort on the aesthetics of the design and the other 50% on people. It's so interesting to see on the extent of "perspective" aspect you should focus as part of the design process. Which makes sense, since after all you are designing and to create for who is using it.

Using design thinking can lead us come up with new ideas and new ways for this course project. As Mr. Brown said: “Design is the way that they create their future”, when it comes to our projects, we should also think of doing something that could contribute our future. Again, since design is based on what people hope and then help people to create things, so we should think of some new ideas and select those good ideas while gradually approaching our projects.
@Eli, do you think this approach can lead to disruptive innovations?
@Wen I agree but Natasha Jen has a very different take on Design Thinking. Check out her talk, "Design Thinking Is Bullsh*t."
@Jia Hui Does "aesthetics" include user experience?

As Mr. Tim Brown provides one approach to the purpose of design thinking is to maximize efficiency and ultimately create values such as new strategies and new partnership, design thinking is really there to help think outside the box. As Mr. Brown later mentions the three phases for design thinking, extreme values on the bell curve, rare things that have never happened before later form into inspirations and innovations. Therefore, I personally consider that design thinking is more about the process rather than the outcome, give. It sparkles to think, even though the result may not be satisfactory, one must learn and improve by brainstorming. As designers for the course projects, we need to connect things that may never be connected and find their unique connections.
@Linjin Thanks for sharing this perspective. Have you heard of Agile Methodologies? What do you think?

When it comes to approaching projects as designers, one has to think about the real-world implications, how it might solve a particular problem, or how to modernize the system. However, most importantly, one has to explore their environment, which might include researching their industry. These factors can serve as an inspiration. In other words, it has to be applicable. As Mr. Brown has stated, “It starts with empathy.” For instance, in the education industry, designers can think about the flaws or unresolved issues in the education system for inspiration, the age of the children that are targeted, brainstorm possible solutions, and create an experiment that places a priority on external validity. However, it is also important to keep teachers in mind when it comes to design thinking.  Mr. Brown called design thinking a “human-scented process.” In the education industry, design can be thought of as a student-teacher process.

After watching this video, I was thinking what is the difference between "Design thinking" and ordinary thinking. In my opinion, the cognitive process people usually use is to think base on their own experience. For example, in most scientific research situations, people search information base of their knowledge (e.g. input keywords they already known). Also, people tend to retrieve memories to deal with similar situations. This kind of thinking often causes confirmation bias, which means you selectively perceive what corresponds with your preexisting hypothesis. Confirmation bias could cause disasters in product development because you are solving your own problem, not the user's.

I believe the "Design thinking" is what we can minimize the effect of confirmation bias. By accurately define who the target audiences are, actually watching participants doing their tasks (or doing the task by ourselves), we could have better insights for the problems.

This course is a very good opportunity to experience online learning. We can definitely find some inconvenience during the process. For me, English is my second language (and is not good enough) so I need more perceptual cues to understand what speaker was saying. I had a very hard time watching the "video in this video". I could barely recognize the words in the sentences even repeated for several times. The sound was not clear enough to make me understand...

I learned about the importance of design thinking, it can be used in different environment and make variety results. Design thinking is the crucial part for innovation. I strongly agree with the three important words for design thinking: Inspiration, Ideation, implementation. This video makes me realize design research is a inspire tool rather than predicate opportunities.

I was inspired by the 3 phases of design thinking mentioned in the presentation: inspiration, ideation, and implementation. Design thinking can help develop our storytelling skills, creativity, logistical thinking, team collaboration, leadership, and implementation capacity for this course project. When we do our projects, we should think about the goals we want to attain or the problems we want to solve. We should also shape our ideas based on people's demands and help them either solve the problems or create things for them. To approach the projects as designers, we need to  think outside of box, select those ideas, and make clear plans to implement our ideas.

From Design to Design Thinking, it breaks the illusion that design is all about making things look cooler or prettier. Instead, it leads us to the concentration of process and the sophistication it takes to really understand people on multiple levels. Just as Mr. Brown says, design thinking starts with empathy, and thus observe and listen to stories are of vital importance. I love the idea of storytelling, for it creates an immersive environment to dive into people’s situation and bring the sense of mission to create a better world through design.

Having insights as the speaker terms it is certainly important. This broadens the perspective from which we make decisions and it takes us out of our comfort zones to make decisions that might inspire the groups we work with or our organizations and affiliations as a whole.

I am surprised about that idea Mr. Tim Brown said that insights come from extreme users. I think the extreme users here not only means the minority of people but also means people's extreme demand. In other words,  to invent something new is a process of meeting people's extreme need and expanding the boundaries of what human can do.  Thus, as Mr. Brown said, it is important for the designer to have a close observation of people and see things from the perspective of them. This gives me an inspiring tip that to gain insight from people rather than just from books.

Stories are indeed a good way to give an in depth description of what to expect as part of the design process. I think a more tangible form of story telling will always be more advantageous because it gives a sense of hope and aspiration for similar future products.

@Can I am with you on your claim that gaining insights from people trumps insights from books. I think the personal interaction we have with others highlights some expectations that users have that we could not have imagined. Without incorporating the opinions and expectations of others the purpose of ensuring great user experience will not be fully achieved.

In the video, 3 phases of design thinking were introduced by the speaker: inspiration, ideation, and implementation. Innovation can hardly be achieved without one another. I am highly inspired by a bell-shaped graph, shading two tails, saying "insights come from extreme users". The users in the middle may bring greater economic profit, but the users at two sides may raise abnormally needs, and that's where innovation starts at.
I think prior to this I might have underestimated the importance of the space you work and collaborate in and how that can affect your thinking/design.

I always love the idea of prototyping and iterating upon concepts instead of waiting for the "perfect" model. It's a wonderful approach that can help you move through mistakes inexpensively. I find it interesting that in some of the traditional research circles I've worked in - iterative "agile" approaches aren't explicitly referred to, but instead the idea of research not being linear is often alluded to.

I believe that design inspires innovation. Approaching design problems is the way to create a future, people investigate the way design contributing to the development of unique product and services in a viable and feasible way. The human design does not always stand as its free field, but it commences with the subject and accomplishes backward from there generating a new idea that’s what inspiration for things might be. It is tough to inspire by other people unless we could sympathize emotionally to understand people on multiple levels which is extremely useful when it comes to designing with cognitive experiences.

From the bell shade, it gives an essential idea that insights come from extremely users. Concern about the large portion of the population which is more predictable but not necessarily gives you the most interesting insights. The idea of this project design of this course is to go the ends of the bell curve looking for extreme users, something potential worthwhile, not just maximize efficiency and ultimately create commercialize values. As long as a business model could solve its industry problems or a particular obstacle in society, It will eventually succeed in the history of human business

I am impressed by the idea that "design thinkers use the world as a source of inspiration not just validation". Sometimes, stereotypes and experiences prevent us from generating new ideas. Mr. Brown points out how to create a new idea: (1) starts with empathy (2) concentrates on extreme situations (3) understands on multiple levels including physical, cognitive and emotional levels. In conclusion, inspiration is people-oriented. For example, design thinking in the education industry, educators and researchers should know students' thoughts in depth, especially those do bad in class, to innovate.

I believe innovation is the essential element to promote the social movement, and the design thinking behind innovation is, as Tim said, the way they create their future, to create new strategies, new market etc. Design thinking is now becoming a trend in different industries, but the most companies still follow the stereotype that constrains their ideas inside a limited space. I think design thinking should be advocated in order to enhance the efficiency in our daily lives, by follow the three phases Mr. Tim Brown mentioned in the video: inspiration, ideation, and implementation.

However, it is hard just to come up with new ideas without any signs because the innovation comes from the experience. To combined what Mr. Tim Brown mentioned, I suggest we should first follow the prototype, plus the learning from experience in order to achieve whatever will be in the final.

this video sheds light upon our common misconception about innovation and over-emphasis on ideation. Instead of mind drifting in the name of brianstorming, inspiration comes from getting out to the real world and empathizing with people. Some useful strategies are introduced such as analogous situation and drawing information from different domains. Also, designing is not problem-solving once for all, iterative prototyping is an essential way to make a design work in different situations. At the same time, getting your design across to others by means of story-telling, instead of cold statistic presentation. All in all, an inspiring video changing daily understanding and intuition about design and setting the stage for innovation by ourselves in the future.

I think it's absolutely important that Brown stresses the importance of "inspiration" and "implementation" as same as "ideation". Good ideas and insights have to be inspired by some unfamiliar experiences instead of coming from the middle of nowhere. It's really interesting to note that stepping out of one's own comfort zone, putting oneself in the shoes of others and experiencing something new, is the key speaking not just of some fields such as cultural and ethnic education, but also of the field of technology and design thinking. Actually, interactions with others and collaboration are applicable to every aspect of our lives.

From Mr. Brown's lecture we can see that the importance of connecting customers and products emotionally and physically through design thinking, as it increases the chance of success of a product strategy, either breaking into a new market segment, or simply maintaining current market position. I totally agree with the bell shape that extreme customers matter in design thinking. To be honest, I think they are whom matters the most in whether a product is standing out or not, comparing to competitors' products. This is because that people are normally able to stand in the shoes of most of the customers, whom interact the most with company or the market, but not the ones that rarely do so. But if a company could come up with a product that catches the attention of more customers than just the ones that would normally like to interact, it would definitely win.

As a result, I'm inspired to think how we could implement design thinking while analyzing products, or education systems. If systems are connected tightly to users, it would probably be effective.

I was impressed by Mr. Brown's three phases in design thinking. I completely agree with his idea that inspiration starts with empathy, which means that designers are supposed to always try putting ourselves in others' shoes to know what exactly target users' feelings are and what they really want, and developing an understanding of those people for whom we are designing the products or services is of great importance. It also encourages designers to go out to observe and explore. As Mr. Brown mentioned before," the whole world is a source of inspiration for design thinkers", I believe it is meaningful for designers to experience things and find inspiration.

While presenting the chart with three sections of the design phase (Inspiration, Ideation, and Implementation) Mr. Brown mentions that most people fall into the trap of spending most of their energy in the ideation portion. He mentions how important that it is to be well rounded in this process, coming up with good inspiration, creating ideas, and then implementing them. I think this underscores the importance of surrounding yourself with people that have different skill sets--ones that can inspire ideas all the way through those who can see through the finishing touches.

Much of this discussion has been around physical products so far, but when shifting the lens towards education--whether that be classroom design, instructional design, an educational product-- I think many of the same ideas apply. Design can't be successful unless it has these three characteristics, inspiration, ideation, and implementation. I think it's rare that one person encompasses all three of these traits fully, so choosing your partners and playing off of eachothers' strengths can really benefit.

I really appreciate how welcoming this toy design group is to new ideas. They respect that these thoughts come in all different shapes and forms. They throw their ideas up on the board and assign it a level of completeness, which I think allows for some great brainstorming. Often is the case that ideas that could result in something, don't ever get mentioned because the owner of the idea is too ashamed to share them in their infancy.

Although the clutter of the work space looks a bit stressful to me, I think they really have something going with their "inspiration" and "ideation". It seems like these designers then pass off the implementation responsibility to some of the larger manufacturers, which I think speaks to my previous point of surrounding yourself with people who have strengths at different points in the design process.

As someone who came from non-design/technology background the whole topic was very new and interesting. I can't agree more about the importance of seeing and thinking with the users' points of view. I believe that everything only becomes realistic and useful when it is designed for a specific use and users.

Mr. Brown stated that a good design thinking comes with three stages: Inspiration, Ideation, and Implementation. We used to be taught that the ideation is the only part (or at less the most important part) when we are going to come up with some new idea and had neglected the processes of where the idea comes from and how to execute the idea in a better way.

For getting some new idea implemented in a most efficient way, Mr. Brown talked about we can using storytelling to develop and express ideas whether to our partners or our targeted consumers. In my opinion, this is another way of working with empathy, just as our inspiration can start with empathy. People know better about how you think during the whole process can have a better understanding of your product.

I like the idea of incorporating several components of "thinking" which excites new insights as a source of inspiration. Also the idea of validation is very interesting to me because it was not necessarily something that I thought of when thinking of design - I was more of the mind of personal interpretation and representation. He speaks of looking through the lens of someone else and not what is of value for one's self.

Mr. Brown said, design is not "the" but "one" approach to innovation. I really wonder what the other approaches are. Design here refers to a "human-centered" process. Therefore, other approaches, in this sense, may be "object-centered", "decentralized" or etc.. It also reminds me of Aristotle's four causes of an entity (i.e. Material Cause, Agent Cause, Formal Cause and Final Cause). At the best of my knowledge, none of the causes is centered of why an entity exist.

Also, Mr. Brown mentioned, "designers create things either what they think the world needs or quite often what they think they need, which is perhaps not the most effective way of doing human-centered innovation. But you know that it can work." Did Mr. Brown contradict his own opinions? What will he do and feel if he works with a designer who is very self-centered? I am very curious about that.

Although a social phobia can be an extremely talented artist, the possibility of it is quite rare. If an average person like me who would like to do some innovations, the three stages of design (i.e. inspiration, ideation and implementation) are very practical to follow.

In a word, to methodize the process of how designers design is very conducive to empower every human being with the ability to create and become a fully developed figure rather than a means of something or someone else.

There is a very surprising point about the relationship between innovation and design thinking: what does design do for innovation? When we see so many new technologies, strategies, and markets etc., how did they get created? If we say, design thinking is supported by a broad and rich set of tools and environments, then we can also think this way: the "new" here means an ongoing process, it means a development process of various things, and this process can be defined with three phases: inspiration (like sprout and hiddenly grow), ideation (formation of the idea) and implementation (really execute and apply). The boundary of the inspiration should not be limited, at least for a good design-thinker, because good innovation can be inspired by a tiny concept.

Empathy also plays a great role. If a design-thinker only think about himself, or things merely around him, it won't be a smart idea. The aim should be aiming to understand multiple groups, and also understand them on multiple levels. Great innovation should be a mixer from various aspects. No matter is for ideation or the implementation phase, building things also needs learning at the same time.

Does "Human-centered" means the interactive process that provides the nice experience for people participated in? Especially for the client or both side of the project, the designer and the client at the same time?

I am very impressed that design thinking is not a methodology but a culture. People with a design-thinking mindset activley engage in the projects to obtain an individual experience for them, which is a great way to cultivate and practice empathy. It is a virtuous cycle. People need to start to learn it by doing it.

Also, the culture may be contagious. The passion to get the thing to the ground can be spread to any facet of the society thereby people get involved can facilitate the multilateral collaboration. People from government, business and academy can definitely communicate to push forward the project.

I think the idea of "learn by prototyping" is very interesting. In general, people's original designs are not perfect. As Brown said, the prototype can happen very quickly and inexpensive. It's an effective way to find problems from the prototype and fix them in the next prototype design. I also like the idea of "a prototype hasn't to be physical but must be tangible", which means a prototype must allow people to build a picture to have a sense of what you have learned. Prototypes may only exist on drawings or computers, but they can help people have a clear understanding of the final product. I think it's also a challenge to make a prototype that is fully capable of showing the finished product and being cheap.

I love the idea of "design thinkers use the world as a source of inspiration not just validation". It is so true especially for marketing innovation. Before conducting marketing research to figure out whether an idea could work on the market, good marketers tend to generate ideas from their surroundings. They get inspiration from the environment and people around them.

I agree with Mr. Brown that marketers of Nike are good story tellers. They use a story to bring an idea alive and get things out into the market. Compared to directly show their products: a pair of shoe or t-shirts to their customer, a good story of products could generate consumers' empathy. Also sometimes stories could help provide the framework for creating ideas and help designers to check if something is missing in the design process. A good story also represents the rationale of design.

Mr.Brown's speech make me think about the relationship between design thinking and innovation. Design Thinking is the creation of solutions to challenges  usually based on ‘a human-based approach’, which means considering users and their needs as the beginning point of developing any new product. We can use a design thinking mindset to enroll in a process of innovation, yet unless the process is successful and measurable , it cannot be said to be innovation.

Mayer stated that learning is caused by instructional method rather than the media. Thus, when it comes to online learning, a multimedia principle should be applied and it should incorporate videos, graphics such as tables, and more in order for students to see a clear picture of the topic. Also, especially if the multimedia supports the information in the textbook, it might enhance the retention of the information. For example, if an instructor decides to post a video of his lecture, is important to adhere to the coherence principle. Otherwise, some students might either get confused or close it without finishing listening to it. However, contiguity principle is not always feasible as some graphics are too complex and might not permit text next to the relevant part of the graphic. As for segmenting principle, it is more effective. For instance, if a student is confused about a certain section, he or she can watch the video containing that section without having to re-watch the whole lecture.
This implies that instructors are supposed to be trained in multimedia instructional design and possess knowledge of these principles and how to efficiently use a video for online learning. Some instructors might be reluctant as it takes time to acquire these skills and to make or search relevant videos. Furthermore, as Mayer mentioned, not all institutions have this technology available since it requires financial resources to hire educational design, cognitive of science learning, and subject matter experts. Moreover, continuous instructors’ training in the use of this technology also requires financial resources. It is also important to note that many students search for videos with explanations of a lecture topic themselves if there is a section in the course material that is unclear to them. Additionally, videos should not replace textbooks or other types of media provided in class. They should only serve as a support to course material and have a purpose. Likewise, as Mayer mentioned, emphasis should be placed on the content rather than production.

Professor Mayer emphasized the significance of visual learning that how you can use visualization to help people learn. For the design of online learning, design graphic makes people learn sufficient since we further know that people learn better from words in pictures than from words alone. In my point of view, I think the designer should concentrate on how to design good graphics including video and how to design good instructional graphics and make a video to help people learn a zero value added the incorporate graphics, not only verbal presentation, especially in k-12 and college education. To look at what is the practical method we can incorporate in video and to keep the presentation simple and focus.

Mr. Mayer makes mainly focus on two ideas: how significant the visual learning and multimedia will be in the learning process; and how to use design graphics in a most effective way. He mentions a really good point of its all based on instructional method. Instructor/teachers need to understand how to present the idea in a clear way and make students understandable. I believe we have all experienced the influence of visual learning, it helps to trigger our interest and desire to learn, to listen and to understand. However, the most concern is how to use the visual learning/multimedia as an efficient medium to help students better understand the materials and knowledge. And this remains an issue today and needs to be discovered.
Visualization makes meaning of the words in the text. Furthermore, using graphics is a good way to summarize relevant information.

EdTech is a hot topic recently, and more traditional education companies are adding online products to their existing lines in order to catch the trend. Certainly, more animations and vivid activities are better than plain words for learners to understand, but too much interactions may cause information overload. Mr. Mayer mentioned one point in the video: it is the instructional design that ease the knowledge transfer for learners, but not the media. We shall use media as a supplement to the traditional class. Also moderate use of media is highly recommended, and using media in class should never replace textbooks.
Also instructor's training on how to use media products is crucial as well. Especially in college where most of the professors are not adept to new technologies, they may get confused with the technologies and eventually not accept the new concept.

I agree with saying it's not the media/visualization that causes one learn more effectively, but the effective instructional design that integrates media and technology to enhance one's learning quality. Often we have restricted access to a variety of learning mediums in the classroom learning environment in a sense that only having the verbal presentation of the learning materials is not enough. Meanwhile, it got me think of the project-based learning we focused on for the first week. The medium of learning is supposed to be as diverse as possible, in a way that it should correspond with the ways we experience and perceive the world -- we not only see and hear, but we take actions and more.

The professor Mayer mentions six principles: (1)multimedia principle: incorporating media into instruction helps people learn better from words and pictures than from words alone (2)coherence principles: keep the presentation simple and focused (3)cotiguilty principle: incorporating the text next to the graphic that is relevant (4)segmenting principle: it's good to break down complicated materials into manageable segments (5)pedagogical principle: good instructional design and sound instructional methods cause learning (6)personalization principle: the voice can be used to help personalize a lesson and helps the learner fell more of a social partnership. He states that just technology available is not useful and we cannot say one medium better than another. When we design video, I think it's good to make the objective clear first, keep the presentation simple and make shorter videos.

The key points of having videos in the learning process are that video corporate with instructional methods help to learn and a good instructional design causes learning ultimately. Professor Mayer illustrates several principles that what makes a good video, which including coherence principle, keep videos simple and focus on a certain point, contiguity principle, put relevant text next to graphics and voice next to the images, and segmenting principle, break down the complicated materials into understandable pieces. Besides, one thing that we should keep in mind is when we design the instructional method is that we should have the instructional objective in mind.

As Mayer talks, I soon connect myself to the phrase "visual learners". As opposed to verbal learners, visual learners are keen to be exposed to knowledge via graphics, charts, and videos. Yet as Mayer continues, he addresses the problem of not providing good and effective online learning experiences. Personalization is key to online learning and it is the hardest when every single individual is so different from one another. I am engaged in an online course outside of TC and am to learn a specific programming language. The core curriculum is split up into 6 parts; under each part, there are multiple lessons and under each lesson, there are 10 - 30 short video lectures on computing commands with length not exceeding 3 minutes. As I learned, I do believe that this is effective learning as every lecture is very focused; all lectures under a lesson are connected; and all lessons under every part is objectively clear. In addition, the advantage of good online learning design is that learners can also go back to previous lectures and review.

The usage of video in teaching is advantageous to engage learners, for it can be used to contextualize the information or provide some background information, which can help learners better understand materials, and achieve cognitive interest. But how we apply videos in class matters. I agree with Prof. Mayer's perspective that it is sound instructional design instead of videos that causes learning. The premise is that the class has clear objectives, and then videos could be an effective complement to it. If not, videos  added to the class are likely to be entertainment.

As professor Mayer said “It is instructional method that causes learning”, neither video nor other new technology could cause study desire. As my understanding, video is just a new medium for learning but the video can not make an instruction become more interesting to students. Instead, it is the instructional content itself. Like Mayer mentioned in the video” Interest should comes from the content itself, not from some external adjunct that you add to it”. I believe it is the instructional method people used could make learning become more interest.

I think Professor Mayer gives a good point about making videos "cognitive interest" rather than "emotional interest". I would think that emotional interest would draw more attention to students and let them be more engaged because they "feel" more. But he's right, it's not the best for education because the ultimate goal is to convey and teach effectively.

Visualizing learning/creating interpretable graphics is important. Multimedia approaches to teaching are essential for online learning and it coincides with theories such as pedagogical content knowledge (Shulman 1986/1987) where representing content in multiple ways is important for learners, and instructors must think deeply about how to represent content in different ways. This requires instructors have a strong subject matter understanding and understand how to pedagogically communicate this to others.

There's also work by Tufte about visualizing information and the ethics of doing so.
I like this point about getting away from looking at only the medium but instead looking at instructional methods and how or whether they align with various methods.
I really like this point that too much detail can be a thing - and this should affect how we design and represent information.

I agree with the idea that instructional method is more important than the medium. A good instructional method is crucial in networked learning, it is necessary to put some graphics next to the text for illustrating and strengthing our memory on this text. I also agree with the coherence principle that it is not a wise choice to give too much detail in the presentation because we are limited in the processing capability. This principle should be considered while design of video for learning,
@Abdul, do you think the use of graphics will be helpful in our traditional classrooms?

I agree with you in this point. Video and multimedia indeed can make learning interactive, engaging, and impressing. However, it is more important to use appropriate teaching methods which can meet students' learning needs and ability.

I heard a lot of popular ideas regarding how technologies empower education, make our learning personalized, and improve learning efficiency. However, it is not edtech tools such as video and multi-media, as professor Mayer mentioned, make our learning more efficient, but the appropriate instruction methods and content development. The video production is also important because it has to correspond to specific parts and important ideas where teacher is talking about and learners can feel easy to follow. I remember some data science courses I am taking through an online program. The slides presentation is broken down to several parts with clear graphics and voice next to the contents in the way that I can know which part is important to learn. I believe my learning is more efficient because every course has specific objectives and clear guidance. After the slide presentation, there are several related practices and slide review, which offer me good opportunities to know if I understand the course contents well.

Professor Meyer points out three principles in instructional multimedia methods designing: coherence, contiguity and segmenting principle. These three principles provide me with insights into the role and design of video for learning, for instance multimedia methods should present contents in a simple, concise and continuous way in order to make people understand. It is critical that complicated topics should be broken down into several sectors, since too much details will make learners feel overloaded and fail to effective learning.
Professor Meyer's view of point to arouse cognitive interest also inspired me. A good instructional multimedia design should impart knowledge in a logic, organized and reasonable way to make students feel interesting about the content itself.

I found this to be a highly interesting point. "It's not really the medium that causes learning, its the instructional method." All too often, this distinction fails to get made and we get school systems who give all their students iPads and then don't understand why their learning objectives success rate is the same. In regards to designing online learning, we should start with considering what types of instructional methods can effectively be applied to this particular medium. Once that decision is made, actual design should be about implementing that method.

Break down a project into small segments. Give instructions, explanations and summarization in multimedia forms, such as a short video or graph. Add personalized instructions such as human voice or image, accompanied with text and images. Now it's getting look like a coding course on Udacity or Codecademy.

"Just making technology available is not enough." Mayer talks about how it must be integrated with the instruction. I feel like a lot of schools and instructors nowadays are simply throwing technology at learners and hoping that it helps. They see others using video/media and feel like they are missing out if they don't incorporate it somehow, however they don't have "clear objectives" as Mayer points out. As more research is conducted, I think it's important to make this actionable and understandable for instructors so they can incorporate these methods with better purpose.

Totally agree with his point ( to achieve cognitive interests) : We should let students be interested in the lesson contents, not to entertain students. For me, to make things clear itself is very awarding. However, when I was teaching some disadvantage students in my country, I felt that they are not so motivated to make things clear. I believe if we can trigger students' curiosity in online courses, we are able to improve students' learning outcome.

Learning with or without visualization makes a huge difference definitely. People tends to prefer at least a little visualization, as just words would make things not really attractive, in fact, people tends to be distracted by just reading articles. As a result, I highly agree with Dr. Mayer that using visualization is the trend in education.

I really agree with Professor Mayer's point. Yes, we all know that multimedia and video plays important role in teaching and understanding especially these days, however, a medium is just a tool that delivers what the instructor wants students to learn. The more important part should be the instructional method and how do we apply the methods together with the tools, and then enables more effective learning and understanding.

When Professor mentioned that too much details will distract people, I am thinking of that instructional design really requires much more than merely design the curriculum or the course. It also requires an understanding of how does human mind work, how does learner process information etc. Making technology available for instructors is not enough. Good instructional designs are more crucial: clear objectives, and then use video and multimedia as the tool to achieve this goal.

Often this would be the most difficult part for instructional designers as many of them usually don't have backgrounds in education but technology. My undergrad paper on philosophy is about "infinitism", a theory of epistemology firmly contended by Professor Peter D. Klein at Rutgers University (2007). He co-authored with John Turri on a book titled, "Ad Infinitum: New Essays on Epistemological Infinitism". Infinitism is a quite old question that can be dated back to Agrippa's Trilemma in Ancient Greek. (An argument can either be circular, in which theory and proof support each other, regressive, in which each proof requires a further proof ad infinitum, or axiomatic, which rests on accepted precepts. However, none of the three can satisfy a skepticist since they are not thoroughly substantiated.)

Nevertheless, Professor Klein argued that infinitism is itself solid and sound to unveil the structure of knowledge, which resonates with Dr. Weinberger here. The fact that the total amount of knowledge is beyond every individual's mental capacity should not be regarded as the evidence that the structure of knowledge could not be infinite. We can of course for the sake of cognitive load set aside some arguments for further discussion, but we can not deny that there are always some questions waiting to be solved as long as we are willing to dig deeply into the topic. And nowadays such a phenomenon is more easily discovered by hyperlinks all over the web page.

Then what should we do? Learning by rote is definitely obsolete while PBL and other new pedagogies need promoting. But should memory as one of our superior cognitive abilities be "abandoned" so rapidly? Is there a best period of time to train such an ability? And what are better content for us to memorize? We may need customized answers for different people. And filters in "The Long Tail" which is also mentioned by Dr. Weinberger in his speech may be a way to find more specialized contents. In practice, so far, ecommerce platforms, like Amazon.com, have done great jobs on it.

The libraries that were proposed by Raine can serve as useful models as they provide real-time information to individuals, which is essential for a learning environment since information and knowledge are constantly updating. There are cases when information provided to learners might already be considered outdated. For instance, it takes time for academic articles to undergo the peer-review process and the updated information to appear in textbooks. However, the libraries envisioned by Rainie might remedy this issue to some extent. As Rainie mentioned, people “chronicle” every event that occurs in their lives. Likewise, due to the popularity of social networks, people access the accuracy and validity of the information that appears on the feeds, thereby, creating a learning community. It introduces people to the type of information that they might not have known about but it might evoke their interest in researching it. The librarians act as arbitrators in the Rainie’s proposed model of libraries. This presents an opportunity for learning communities to interact with the librarians. In other words, both educators and learners can benefit from this model of libraries.

Rainie emphasized some new important roles for libraries and librarians today " in response to the era of social media. Given the fact that learning has come to be a 'process' and knowledge tends to be fluid and current today, there is no way the librarians can be an expert at anything that they pass down to learners. Therefore, it's the very key that library should adopt a collaborative approach in terms of information sharing and take full advantage of social networks to "do what they do best and link to the rest".

In this bit, Rainie discusses reference expertise, "Taking individuals and communities outside their known boundaries." Essentially, the goal in this type of consulting is to bring information to individuals that they didn't know about, and thus could not have explored on their own, but that they will care about once it has been brought to their attention. This reminds me of a point Dr. Natriello brought up during our last in class meeting where oftentimes he is limited in his exploration by knowledge due to a lack of even knowing the correct word or phrase that he should be searching in order to get to the topic he wants to know about. In response to the posted question, it seems that this is a model libraries could adapt for online learning. They can act a central database which serves to answer not just the questions that the individual arrives with but also to engage with the individual to diversify their knowledge base beyond what they were previously capable of.

I believe Wikipedia is a great tool for people to gather the useful and new information they want to know and for me, as a wikipedia user, really enjoy and appreciate the easy access to this kind of "online library" in my life. First of all, it's definite that Wikipedia cannot remove its restrictions on editing its posts. For instance, I think it would be fair to have a group of people who maybe don't know each other to work on one post to ensure that the final post is at least in some sort clear and fair with no bias. The selection on this group could be based upon some standards, for instance their position in certain organizations or some sort of related certificates. Moreover, there are some posts that contains soft content, that may be able to be edited by the public, as long as the result does not have unsuitable words. The result could be posted directly, but the public could report it if there is any mistake. In a word, I think categorizing posts and sort them through different ways could help a lot to balance openness and accuracy.

In a new educational system which focuses on preparing students for diverse lives, what can satisfy their respective needs can no longer be predetermined curricula.
